main event: Three long, thin, and bright objects were observed in Billings, Montana in 1958 for 1 hour and 10 minutes. They displayed unusual movement patterns, circling and leaving vapor-like trails before moving south at a moderate speed.
interesting points: The objects were described as thinner and longer than cigars with a vertical outline, and they were observed to be very bright and golden with fuzzy outlines.
The first object was stationary when first sighted, then two more objects of the same size and shape moved toward it, and all three eventually moved south at a moderate speed.
The observation was made by three civilians for over an hour, and the objects were visible both with the naked eye and through binoculars.
The conclusion drawn from the observation was that it was a probable interplay of the sun's slant rays on scattered clouds, suggesting a natural phenomenon rather than an extraterrestrial event.
The document also discusses lenticular clouds and their potential to be mistaken for flying saucers due to their lens-like effect, which distorts the appearance of distant objects.
sighted object: three long, thin, and bright objects in a loose group
